awd_titl_txt: Innovation in the Bioeconomy:  Workshops to catalyze translation and partnerships
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is intended to fund a series of five biotechnology-related workshops around the following themes (i) Feeding the Planet Sustainably, (ii) World Without Waste: a circular bioeconomy, (iii) Towards a Healthier Planet: from molecules to ecosystems, (iv) Biological Mitigation of Climate Change, and (v) Bioeconomy Ecosystem and Society. Each of these themes will have a set of four overarching goals (a) Examine biotechnology areas associated with significant societal challenge where increased research could yield translatable impacts; (b) Explore interdisciplinary science areas where a virtuous cycle of discovery and innovation over a sustained period is possible; (c) Identify areas ripe for partnerships that will leverage expertise and resources across sectors; and (d) Catalyze the research community to engage in translation, innovation, and partnership at speed and scale. Overall, the workshops are intended to address the required needs to bridge the disconnect among discovery, innovation, and translation into practice by assembling for discussion the necessary expertise from interdisciplinary teams across academia and industry to co-generate knowledge, discovery, and innovation to enable the translation to practice at speed and scale. The five workshops will be held using an on-line platform. The series of workshop will contribute to the enhancement and improvement of scientific, engineering, and/or educational activities by convening experts to address the societal challenges of producing food sustainably, creating a circular bioeconomy that will reduce waste, using advances in biotechnology to improve health, leveraging biotechnology to mitigate the impacts of climate change, and exploring the unique aspects of bioeconomy innovation ecosystems.

Advances in biotechnology, synthetic and engineering biology are producing rapid economic growth and are leading to novel biomaterials, transforming the food, agriculture and pharmaceutical industries, enabling new capabilities for information storage and renewable energy and creating new kinds of targeted medical therapies. To achieve the full translational potential of these research advances, there is a need to bring together experts and practitioners in biotechnology and associated fields from academia, industry, and other parts of the broader ecosystem of stakeholders to engage in a virtuous cycle of discovery and innovation that will yield societal impacts. This series of five workshops, focused on different grand societal challenges, contemplates new paradigms of engagement between academic and industrial sectors that are necessary to create the requisite environment to foster both discovery and innovation that leads to rapid translation.

This award is co-funded by the Directorates for Biological Sciences; Computer and Information Sciences and Engineering; Engineering; Geosciences; Mathematical and Physical Sciences; and Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences; along with the Office of Integrative Activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Innovation in the Bioeconomy: Workshops to catalyze translation and partnerships 

 Award #2137471

 

Over billions of years, life has evolved a vast diversity of innovations?solutions to overcome environmental challenges. Until recently, our ability to understand these innovations has been limited. But new capabilities to read and edit genomes, new means of sensing biological processes at multiple scales, and new computational approaches in bioinformatics have vastly improved our ability to understand and exploit life?s deepest mysteries. Engineering and synthetic biology approaches are enabling the translation of these fundamental discoveries for economic and societal prosperity.

Biotechnology, synthetic, and engineering biology are producing extremely fast economic growth and hold immense potential for transformative change across many commercial sectors. Advances in these fields are leading to novel biomaterials; transforming the food, agriculture, and biotechnology industries; enabling new capabilities for information storage and renewable energy; and creating new kinds of targeted medical therapies.

In all, five innovation in the bioeconomy workshops were developed in coordination with supporting academic institutions and technical advisory committees for each theme.  The workshops were conducted with the use of a virtual platform over a two-day period for each visioning workshop event.  The series of completed workshops are as follows:

  •  Feeding the Planet Sustainably (July 28-29, 2021)
  • Creating a World Without Waste via a Circular Bioeconomy (August 19-20, 2021)
  • Building a Biotechnology Innovation Ecosystem to Mitigate Climate Change (October 12-13, 2021)
  • Economic and Societal Challenges of Biotechnology (April 20-21, 2022)
  • Innovation Ecosystems for Adaptive Sustainable Health (May 10-11, 2022)

Each workshop convened stakeholders from multiple sectors and disciplines to identify the primary levers by which increased research activity could yield results that translate into real-world solutions. Workshop participants represented academia, industry, and government, working together to identify research areas ripe for partnership and collaboration. For each topic, an NSF working group and a Technical Task Force of experts shaped the content and discussion areas of exploration.

The series of workshops contributed to the enhancement and improvement of scientific, engineering, and educational activities by convening experts to address the societal challenges of producing food sustainably, creating a circular bioeconomy that will reduce waste, using advances in biotechnology to improve health, and leveraging biotechnology to mitigate the impacts of climate change. The workshops stressed cross-sector partnerships spurring translational activity for even greater impact. Diverse speakers and participants were included to ensure a robust exchange of ideas that led to a more equitable and inclusive scientific enterprise. The online platform enabled active and passive participation by many stakeholders who would not have been able to participate in on-site events. The results were disseminated on public websites in print and via video recording and incorporate actionable next steps for consideration for adoption by participants and other interested parties.

 

Published reports and executive summaries for each workshop within the bioeconomy series may be found within the UIDP Resource Center:  

https://uidp.org/custom-type/innovation-in-the-bioeconomy-reports/
